definitions.definition: to give somebody the desire, confidence or enthusiasm to do something well
definitions.sensetop: inspire somebodyinspire somebody with somethinginspire somebody to somethinginspire somebody to do something

examples.text: The actors' enthusiasm inspired the kids.
The actors inspired the kids with their enthusiasm.
His superb play inspired the team to a thrilling 5–0 win.
We hope to inspire others to pursue their dreams.
The director inspired everybody on the project.
As a teacher, she has inspired generations of students.
He was inspired to write the song following the birth of his daughter.

definitions.definition: to give somebody the idea for something, especially something artistic or that shows imagination

examples.text: The choice of decor was inspired by a trip to India.
His tragic story later inspired a Hollywood film.
Her paintings were clearly inspired by Monet’s work.
It was this trip that helped to inspire his interest in Eastern thought.

definitions.definition: to make somebody have a particular feeling or emotion
definitions.sensetop: inspire somebody with somethinginspire something in somebody

examples.text: Henry did not **inspire confidence** as a figure of authority.
Her work didn't exactly **inspire me with confidence**.
As a general, he inspired great loyalty in his troops.
The council's record in this area inspires little respect.
She is a young woman who inspires trust in everyone she meets.

wordOrigin: Middle English enspire, from Old French inspirer, from Latin inspirare ‘breathe or blow into’ from in- ‘into’ + spirare ‘breathe’. The word was originally used of a divine or supernatural being, in the sense ‘impart a truth or idea to someone’.
